awd_titl_txt: Conference on Quantum Symmetries: Tensor Categories, Topological Quantum Field Theories, and Vertex Algebras
awd_abstract_narration:
Symmetry is all around us and, as such, forms a crucial tool to understand the natural world. Mathematicians have studied symmetries for hundreds of years and these classical results have guided almost every area of applied science. In the microscopic world, however, it is the counterintuitive rules of quantum science that must be obeyed. Scientists studying these phenomena therefore turn to a newly created field of mathematics known as quantum symmetry. While new, this field has already led to many breakthroughs and has played a crucial role in work that has been awarded several recent Fields medals and Nobel prizes. This project will bring together leading international experts and early career researchers from mathematics and physics to share techniques and advances in quantum symmetry. It will take place at the Centre de Recherches Mathématiques (CRM), Montreal, Canada, from October 10 to November 4, 2022, and will feature three weeks of lectures courses and a one-week international conference. For more information, see the conference website: http://www.crm.umontreal.ca/2022/Quantum22/index_e.php

The topics of this event are important both in mathematics and physics. In mathematics, the latest developments in the representation theory of quantum groups at roots of unity bring new results to this well-developed subject. Related developments in topological quantum field theory (TQFT) and vertex algebras (VA) clarify the structure of "non-semisimple" TQFT and VA. Many recent conferences in these areas of research have focused on parts of these connections, but this conference will be unique in the sense that it will feature talks on each of the following topics: conformal field theories, vertex operator algebras, Hopf algebras and fusion categories, tensor categories in positive characteristic, constructions of modular categories, cohomological aspects of tensor categories, and more.  These activities will connect communities working on different sides of the rich research area that is quantum symmetry. Other important aims include the training of the next generation of mathematical scientists and creating opportunities to meet with other researchers working on related problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported US-based participants and US citizens to attend a
one-month program at the Centre de Recherches Mathematiques, Universite
de Montreal, in November 2022.  The topic was "quantum symmetries", a
relatively new and exciting branch of mathematical physics that is
becoming increasingly important for cutting-edge mathematical research.
The program itself consisted of three weeks of lecture courses, including problem sessions,

and a one-week international conference featuring some of the biggest names in
the field.

The main outcome of the very generous NSF funding is that we were able
to provide financial support to eight senior speakers and eighteen
junior participants, many of whom also gave short research talks during
the lecture weeks.  The junior funding was essential for many attendees,
particularly those from traditionally underrepresented groups, and so
directly contributed to the program's goal of educating a new generation
in the increasingly important methods of quantum symmetry and 

the interactions between the different approaches to it, 

which is fundamental given the interdisciplinary essence of the topic.

This increased attendance led to significantly improved interactions
between participants, particularly among junior attendees.  Feedback
repeatedly emphasized how successful this aspect of the program was, eg.

* "It was great to meet so many junior mathematicians and talk to them.
Very stimulating!"

* "I definitely liked how the program was scheduled. It had a lot of
opportunities to digest the content of the courses while providing a lot
of settings to interact with other mathematicians. I think it was an
excellent experience to enhance my professional growth. The choice of
speakers and the content of the courses was also very of my liking."

* "The mini-courses were outstanding. They provided an excellent
introduction to topics that were new to me and deepened my understanding
of areas that were more familiar to me. This program was excellent, and
I feel incredibly lucky to have had the opportunity to attend it."

The enhanced interactions also led to new collaborations that have
resulted in a plethora of research articles.  In addition, the
organizers are preparing an issue of the American Mathematical Society's

series Contemporary Mathematics featuring 14 of these.
